ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: A good understanding of the most important parts of how the EU is structured and why it is influential. Also how to write a policy memo.

Up to date knowledge on recent developments in the EU sphere. Policy memo writing (this course is particularly super helpful because prof. Amand gives you detailed sets of feedback on your policy memos - one for the rough drafts, one for the final drafts). Economic concepts that are practical in understanding international relationships within and involving the EU. EU history, structure, mechanisms, strengths, weaknesses, perceptions, role, etc.
Overview of EU structure and current issues

We covered the history and institutions of the European Union, the causes and effects of Brexit, and the intricacies of international trade controls, monetary policy, and interests rates. We learned to write policy action memos that were concise and effective.
A better understanding of Europe through both a political and economic lens, and the ability to critically engage with the issue.
I learned about the EU, the economics underpinning it and the history of crises in the EU.

This class provided a holistic overview of the historical, political, and economic integration of Europe and the EU since the 1950s. We started with a brief overview of Europe at the time of the ~WWII era and covered topics until present day, including Brexit, the eurozone sovereign debt crisis, and the Greek debt crisis. We also talked about the history of the euro and the implications for future integration. I came into this course with literally 0 knowledge about the EU, and I am much more familiar with how the EU works, its institutions, and its history.
I learned the history, economic fundamentals, and political struggle behind the most pressing issues in Europe today, and gained insight into the mind of an economic policymaker

- what led to the formation of the Eurozone 
-deep understanding of how all aspects of the European economy and diplomacy around it work 
- how the European economy affects national politics and vice versa 
- causes and consequences of Brexit 
- insights on what could have been done differently to avoid the Greek crisis and how to avoid such a eurozone-crisis in the future
-applicable knowledge for all of us wishing to follow a career in European diplomacy 
- the memo and the orals were very similar to what could be asked from us in a professional environment and thus gave us communication, writing and presentation skills useful for our future careers
A great grasp of the history and challenges of the EU!

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths - Arguably interesting material, paired with a professor that teaches it really well and elevates said material to be engaging for sure. + A lot of students from across Europe take this course, so it's super fun to hear their personal experiences and takes.
 / 
Weaknesses - eh. Can't think of anything.

Strength: the readings and method of teaching. Gave good background regardless of how much expertise people came into the class with. Also the one-on-one feedback on memos.
Weakness: too long spent on initial structure if EU that could have been spent on the later half of the course

Strengths: Flexibility to pursue current events or other topics students find interesting, assignments designed to prepare students for the real world, and depth of understanding of the topics covered.
Weaknesses: We got slightly behind schedule which led to us moving assignments around and the readings not always lining up with the class day, which was difficult.
Very much an excellent lecture/seminar hybrid, the readings could be a bit dense but worth it to stay engaged with the course.

Professor Amand is a great professor who really knows what he's talking about. The course is structured very well and the feedback is good. The readings are also interesting. Sometimes the format is quite lecture-heavy, but it's a lot of content to get through and Professor Amand is very knowledgeable.

Strength = Marnix is an amazing professor who is super knowledgeable about economics in general and more specifically the EU. He speaks super fast, but he knows so much and is very willing to share his ideas. Definitely go to his office hours if you need help but also if you want to chat more about stuff you have been covering in class -- I had some really great debates with him. Also, I liked writing the policy memos, as those were actually super realistic and practical and really forced us (my group mate and I) to apply what we had learned in class to a real life exercise. Finally, I surprisingly enjoyed the oral final exam -- do not be intimidated at all! I was definitely super nervous going in and wasn't sure what to expect, but it is actually a really great exercise (it is more like a conversation on the EU than getting grilled on it) and I realized I had learned a lot more than I thought I had which was super awesome!
Weakness = don't get grades back right away, but also don't worry about that as long as you are doing the readings and putting in the work on the pset and policy memos and in class you will turn out fine grade-wise (I promise).
The lectures were fascinating and the readings usually were a great supplement to them.  No real flaws.

-Professor Amand is extremely knowledgeable and experienced in European economics and diplomacy. He always asked questions that made the seminars very interesting and interactive and talked about recent developments and news of the European Economy. He is definitely a great strength of the course. 
- the assignments helped us understand the content in depth and critically think, preparing us for assignments in our future professions
-the discussions in class were very engaging and well-rounded 
-no weaknesses!

It's an amazing course! The readings can be a bit technical at times, but Prof. Amand really just wants you to have a solid grasp by the end--he's not out to trick you. He really is the biggest strength of the course.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: YES
Yes! I learned so much, was excited to go to class, and never felt like I was doing busy work/work that wasn't directly helping my understanding of the material.

If you're interested at all in international relations and especially Europe, absolutely take this. Honestly tho even if you're not that interested, still take it. Prof. Amand does a really good job of teaching the material so that it's interesting regardless.
Yes!

Absolutely. Professor Amand is a gem. Super nice but really knows his stuff and will make you learn! This class is also super practical, he doesn't make you learn for the sake of it but so that you could reproduce it in a realistic scenario. The feedback on the policy memos is very helpful and the oral exam is probably the best final I've taken at Yale.
Yes, absolutely. Prof. Amand is one of the most intelligent professors I have come across.
Yes! This class is a great introduction to the EU and its economics. It's a lot of fun, and the class discussions are great. Professor Amand is very invested in teaching, and it shows.

Yes! I would definitely recommend to another student. Marnix is an awesome professor and you will learn so much from him -- this is my second class with him and I still love him. I would recommend this class to students who are interested in the EU, and would definitely recommend to those who do not know anything about the EU. You don't have to know anything to take this class, Marnix will teach you! I came into this class knowing nothing and I have walked away with a much better understanding of the history of the EU and how it works. Now, I feel I could have an intelligent conversation or read the news about the EU and understand what is going on/what is at stake. Please take this class if you can get in!
Absolutely!  If you have any interest in Europe at all and have studied some economics  during your Yale career, you will learn a lot and really gain expertise on the EU.

I would definitely recommend this class to Econ majors who want to focus on the European market, all global majors and anyone interested in learning more about how the EU works! Speaking from personal experience, it is a particularly interesting class also for people who are European or have some personal experience with any of the past events the class analyzes. It helps students understand how the European market works by also focusing on how the EU works, which is unique to the whole world as a structure and thus interesting to everyone.
Yes! If you're interested in having a working understanding of the EU, the Euro, the history of EU debt crises, etc., this is a great class. Don't worry about not being good at econ!
